{{redirect-distinguish|Part-Time Scientists|citizen scientist|scientist}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = ALINA (Autonomous Landing and Navigation Module) | names_list = <!--list of previous names if the spacecraft has been renamed. Include the dates applicable if possible, and separate each name with a linebreak. Omit if the spacecraft has only ever been known by one name. Do not include Harvard, COSPAR/NSSDC or SATCAT/NORAD/NASA designations as alternative names-->
<!--image of the spacecraft/mission--> | image = File:Rover "Asimov Jr. R3" bei Fahrtests.jpg | image_caption = Prototype rover ''Asimov Jr. R3'' during test drives in [[Eisenerz (Steiermark)|Eisenerz]], Austria, end of April 2012 | image_alt = <!--image alt text--> | image_size = <!--include px/em; defaults to 220px-->
<!--Basic details--> | mission_type = Robotic lander and rovers | operator = Part-Time Scientists | COSPAR_ID = <!--spacecraft launched since 1963 only (aka NSSDC ID; eg. 1998-067A)--> | SATCAT = <!--satellite catalogue number, omit leading zeroes (e.g. 25544)--> | website = {{URL|http://mission-to-the-moon.com/}} | mission_duration = <!--How long the mission lasted--> | distance_travelled = <!--How far the spacecraft travelled (if known)-->
<!--Spacecraft properties--> | spacecraft = ALINA <!--Spacecraft name/serial number (eg. Space Shuttle ''Discovery'', Apollo CM-118), etc--> | spacecraft_type = <!--eg. GPS Block II, Kobalt-M, US-K, etc--> | spacecraft_bus = <!--eg. A2100M, Star-2, etc--> | manufacturer = <!--company or companies who built the satellite--> | launch_mass = <!--fuelled mass at launch, not including rocket or upper stage--> | BOL_mass = <!--spacecraft mass in orbit at beginning of operational life, after LEOP phase--> | landing_mass = <!--Mass after landing (recovered spacecraft only)--> | dry_mass = <!--spacecraft mass in orbit without fuel--> | payload_mass = <!--Mass of cargo carried by spacecraft (eg. for Space Shuttle), or total mass of instrumentation/equipment/experiments for mission--> | dimensions = <!--body dimensions and solar array span--> | power = <!--end-of-life power, in watts-->
<!--Launch details--> | launch_date = 2019 (proposed) <!--{{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|hh|mm|ss|TZ=Z}}--> | launch_rocket = [[Falcon 9]] | launch_site = <!--Where the rocket launched from, including complex and pad; do not include the full address or country--> | launch_contractor = [[SpaceX]]
| landing_date = <!--when the spacecraft made a controlled landing, not needed if it did not return intact--> | landing_site = [[Taurus–Littrow]] (proposed) <!--where the craft landed; site/runway or coordinates-->
|interplanetary = <!--Infobox spaceflight/IP can be called multiple times for missions with multiple targets or combined orbiter/lander missions, etc--> {{Infobox spaceflight/IP |type = rover |object = [[Moon]] <!--body visited - e.g. Jupiter, Venus, etc--> |component = <!--part of the spacecraft involved, if spacecraft split into multiple components--> |arrival_date = <!--Flybys: date/time of closest approach; Orbiters; orbital insertion date; Impactors/Landers/Rovers: impact/landing date/time; Atmospheric probes: atmospheric entry time--> |location = <!--landing/impact site, including EOM impacts for atmospheric probes and lunar/asteroid orbiters--> |distance = <!--closest approach distance for flybys, distance travelled on surface for rovers, omit for others--> }}
<!--transponder parameters--> | trans_band = <!--Transponder frequency bands--> | trans_frequency = <!--specific frequencies--> | trans_bandwidth = <!--bandwidth--> | trans_capacity = <!--capacity of the transponders--> | trans_coverage = <!--area covered--> | trans_TWTA = <!--TWTA output power--> | trans_EIRP = <!--equivalent isotropic power--> | trans_HPBW = <!--half-power beam width--> }}
'''PTScientists''', formerly known as '''Part-Time Scientists''', is a group of volunteer scientists and engineers based in Germany. They became the first German team to officially enter the [[Google Lunar X-Prize]] competition on June 24, 2009,<ref>[http://ptscientists.com/docs/PR_2009-06-24_XPrize.pdf German Team Part-Time Scientists enters $30-million Google Lunar X-Prize Competition]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Part-Time Scientists, 2009-06-24. (PDF, English)</ref> which was finished without winner in March 2018. Their goal remains to land a mission on the Moon by 2019.<ref name='4G Network'>{{cite news |title=VODAFONE AND NOKIA TO CREATE FIRST 4G NETWORK ON MOON |url=http://www.vodafone.com/content/index/media/vodafone-group-releases/2018/vodafone-and-nokia-to-create-first-4g-network-on-moon.html |work=www.vodafone.com}}</ref>
==Moon landing== [[File:584392main M168000580LR ap17 area.jpg|thumb|The planned landing site for ALINA is next to the [[Apollo 17]] lander, located at [[Taurus–Littrow]] ]] In March 2017, the group announced that they planned to perform the world's first private [[Moon landing]].<ref name=telegraph>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/2017/03/19/european-rocket-scientists-pledge-make-first-private-moon-landing/|title=European rocket scientists pledge to make first private Moon landing in 2018|date=19 March 2017|work=[[Daily Telegraph]]}}</ref> A landing module called ''Autonomous Landing and Navigation Module'' (ALINA) will launch on a [[Falcon 9]] to the surface of the Moon.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/2017/03/19/european-rocket-scientists-pledge-make-first-private-moon-landing/|title=European rocket scientists pledge to make first private Moon landing in 2018}}</ref> ALINA lander will deploy two lunar rovers in the [[Taurus–Littrow]] lunar valley, that will search for the [[Lunar Roving Vehicle]] left there by [[NASA]] astronauts [[Eugene Cernan]] and [[Harrison Schmitt]] in 1972 during the [[Apollo 17]] mission.<ref name=telegraph/>
The rovers are being developed by German automobile manufacturer [[Audi]].<ref name='The Mission'>[http://mission-to-the-moon.com/press-release/ The Mission]. PTScientists' lunar mission home page. Accessed 12 July 2018.</ref><ref name=Audi>[https://www.audi.com/en/innovation/mttm.html 45 years after the last step on the moon, we are ready to take the next one.] Audi. Accessed: 1 October 2018.</ref> The prototype rover is called ''Asimov Jr. R3'', while the two flight rovers are named ''Audi Lunar Quattro''.<ref name=Audi/><ref>[https://uk.news.yahoo.com/ptscientists-apos-mission-moon-apos-172800261.html?guccounter=1 PTScientists 'Mission to the Moon' to Take Care Not to Harm Apollo 17 Landing Site]. Robert Z. Pearlman, ''Yahoo News''. 7 December 2017.</ref> ALINA lander will also perform communications relay between the rovers and Earth, using technology based on [[Infineon Technologies|Infineon]] chips, Nokia, and Vodafone's 4G LTE network.<ref name='4G Network'/><ref name='The Mission'/>
===Payload=== The lander and rovers may carry commercial payloads or scientific instruments for a fee. The only confirmed payload to date is hardware for a live video broadcast.<ref name='The Mission'/>
==History== The Part-Time Scientists team formed in June 2009, when ten teams had already entered [[Google Lunar X-Prize]] (GLXP), which had started in 2007. Later the company Part-Time Scientists GmbH (Limited) was founded.
On August 22–23, 2009, the Part-Time Scientists presented their project at the Open Doors Day of the [[Federal Ministry for Education and Research]].{{citation needed|date=August 2012}}
On December 28, 2009, the team presented their mission at the 26th annual [[Chaos Communication Congress]]. In a two-hour presentation, the team provided a detailed overview of all parts of the project. This was the first time the European-made private [[lunar rover]] prototype had been presented to the public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/26C3-Wie-eine-Handvoll-Hacker-den-Mond-erobern-will-893241.html|title=26C3: Wie eine Handvoll Hacker den Mond erobern will|first=heise|last=online|website=heise online}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.happytimes.ch/news-welt/264-20091228-deutsche-erobern-mond.html|title=Deutsches Team will Mond erobern und 30 Millionen Dollar gewinnen|publisher=}}</ref>
Early 2015 the team won awards in the categories Mobility and Vision, and a total of $750,000 in the Milestone Prizes of [[Google Lunar X-Prize|GLXP]].<ref>[http://www.space.com/28365-google-lunar-xprize-milestones.html Google Lunar XPrize Milestone Awards Announced] Accessed 2016-03-29</ref>
During the Advertising Festival in [[Cannes]], on June 23, 2015, [[Audi]] was announced as a main sponsor and the rover developer.<ref>[http://ptscientists.com/ ptscientists.com] Accessed 2016-06-27</ref><ref>[http://microsites.audi.com/mission-to-the-moon/de/ Mission to the Moon] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160704233645/http://microsites.audi.com/mission-to-the-moon/de/ |date=July 4, 2016 }} Accessed 2016-06-27</ref> As a result of this cooperation, the two identical rovers were named ''Audi Lunar Quattro'' during the 2016 [[North American International Auto Show]] in Detroit.<ref>The Verge: [https://www.theverge.com/2016/1/11/10746926/audi-lunar-rover-xprize-detroit-auto-show-2016 Inside Audi's wonderfully improbable project to put a rover on the Moon] Accessed 2016-03-29</ref>
== Part-Time Scientists GmbH == {{Infobox company | name = Part-Time-Scientists GmbH | logo = <!-- [[File:Image Part-Time-Scientists Logo.png|170px]] --> | caption = | type = | traded_as = | genre = <!-- Only used with media and publishing companies --> | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | founder = | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location_city = Berlin | location_country = Germany | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Robert Böhme | industry = | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = <!-- Only used with financial services companies --> | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|http://ptscientists.com}} | footnotes = | intl = }}
''Part-Time Scientists GmbH'' is the company representing the team. The company opened offices in [[Berlin-Mahlsdorf]] in 2015. It also uses the name ''PTScientists''.
Part-Time Scientists GmbH is reselling payload on the Moon mission to individuals, organizations and companies. The cost for one kilogram of payload is between €700,000 and €800,000.<ref name="PTSpayload">[http://ptscientists.com/products/payload/ ptscientists.com/products/payload ALINA's payload]. Accessed October 15, 2017.</ref> Furthermore, the know-how of the team is available as a [[consulting]] service.<ref name="PTSconsultancy">[http://ptscientists.com/products/engineering-consultancy/ ptscientists.com/products/engineering-consultancy] Accessed Oktober 15, 2017</ref> The [[European Space Agency]] is currently studying six private companies, including PTScientists, to work on potential [[ISRU]] payload delivery to the Moon surface by 2025.<ref>[https://ptscientists.com/giving-esa-a-helping-hand-to-the-moon/ Giving ESA a helping hand to the Moon]. PTScientists News Release. 26 April 2018.</ref>
An additional source of income are [[merchandising]] products for the Moon mission.<ref name="PTSshopImprint">[https://mission-to-the-moon.shop/epages/80e22e9a-4d0c-4df8-8eea-a7b75b3f4c42.sf/en_GB/?ViewObjectPath=%2FShops%2F80e22e9a-4d0c-4df8-8eea-a7b75b3f4c42%2FCategories%2FImprint Imprint] auf mission-to-the-moon.shop. Accessed Oktober 15, 2017</ref>
=== Partners === Part-Time Scientists lists as their partners:<ref>[http://ptscientists.com/partners/ ptscientists.com/partners]. Accessed 2016-10-15</ref><ref>http://mission-to-the-moon.com/ Mission to the Moon]. PTScientists. Accessed 12 July 2018.</ref> {{colbegin}} '''Key partners''' * [[Audi]] * [[Infineon Technologies]] * [[Omega SA]] * On (a Swiss shoe manufacturer) * [[Vodafone]]
'''Mission scientific and academic partners''' * [[German Aerospace Center]] * [[University of Würzburg]] * [[Université Internationale de Rabat|International University of Rabat]]
'''Mission technology partners''' * [[Riedel]] * [[SCISYS]]
'''Mission supporters''' * [[Altium]] * CMOSIS * [[For All Moonkind, Inc.]] * [[FreeFlyer]] * Grünwald Electronic * [[Hamburg University of Technology]] * Jama * LeitOn * MindMeister * [[Nokia Bell Labs]]<ref name='4G Network'/><ref>[https://www.nokia.com/en_int/news/releases/2018/02/27/nokia-is-selected-by-vodafone-to-be-its-technology-partner-for-mission-to-the-moon-project Nokia is selected by Vodafone to be its technology partner for Mission to the Moon project]. Nokia Press Release. Accessed 12 July 2018.</ref> * Profitbricks * [[Quast]] * [[Red Bull GmbH|Red Bull]] * RoboDrive * [[Schneider Kreuznach]] * Schulz Electronic * [[SLM Solutions Group AG|SLM Solutions]] * SolidLine {{colend}}

'''Pavel Kononovich Senko''' ({{lang-ru|Павел Кононович Сенько}}) (October 4, 1916 – 2000) was a [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[polar explorer]], [[scientist]], and member and leader of numerous expeditions to [[Arctic Ocean]] and [[Antarctica]] under the auspices of the [[Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute]] and [[Soviet Antarctic Expedition]].
There is a valley at the bottom of Arctic Ocean named after him : ''Senko Valley'' from 87° 04’ N 97° 00’ W to 87° 45’ N 101° 10’ W . There is a mountain named after him in Antarctica: ''Senko Mountain'' at 71° 25,2’ S 12° 46,8’ E on the [[Zavaritsky Ridge]].
He was leader of the winter party and officer-in-charge of [[Mirny Station]] on the [[9th Soviet Antarctic Expedition]] and lead several expeditions subsequently. His name had shown up in the 1997 edition of "The Guinness Book of records" as one of the four "first people to have indisputably reached the North Pole at ground level exactly 90°00`00" (+-300m) on April, 23, 1948" [https://books.google.ru/books?id=NRc7h5gisY8C&dq=Kuznetsov%3Dfalse&q=Kuznetsov&redir_esc=y#v=snippet&q=Kuznetsov&f=false]
==Publications==
* Senko, P. K. (1963) "The Coast Effect in the Variations of the Earth's Electromagnetic Field" in ''Journal of Geomagnetism and Geoelectricity'' (XV) 271,
==External links== *{{ru icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20070930224748/http://www.aari.nw.ru/projects/Antarctic/persons/senko/senko_ru.html Biography] *{{ru icon}} [[:ru:Павел Кононович Сенько|Russian Wiki page]] *{{ru icon}} [http://www.aari.ru/misc/publicat/paa/PAA-110/111-115.pdf Valley and Mountain Senko to 100 – Anniversary with Day Birth Pavel Kononovich Senko] [https://books.google.ru/books?id=NRc7h5gisY8C&pg=PA88&dq=9780595214549&hl=ru&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjRidPkyvvXAhWHNpoKHZAlB1QQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=9780595214549&f=false Cristopher Pala The oddest Place on the earth - Rediscovering the North Pole]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Senko}} [[Category:1916 births]] [[Category:2000 deaths]] [[Category:Russian and Soviet polar explorers]] [[Category:Russian explorers]] [[Category:Explorers of Antarctica]]
{{Russia-scientist-stub}} {{geoscientist-stub}}

{{For|sporting events canceled because of inclement weather|rainout (sports)}}
A '''rainout''' is the process of precipitation causing the removal of radioactive particles from the atmosphere onto the ground, <ref>{{cite web |url = http://iis-db.stanford.edu/pubs/20063/NuclearRisk.pdf |format = PDF |title = Communicating Nuclear Risk |accessdate = 2007-05-11 |author = Tonya L. Putnam |date = May 20, 2002 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070610233310/http://iis-db.stanford.edu/pubs/20063/NuclearRisk.pdf |archivedate = June 10, 2007 |df = }}</ref> creating [[nuclear fallout]] by rain. The rainclouds of the rainout are often formed by the particles of a [[nuclear explosion]] itself and because of this, the decontamination of rainout is more difficult than a "dry" fallout.
==Factors affecting rainout== A rainout could occur in the vicinity of [[ground zero]] or the contamination could be carried aloft before deposition depending on the current [[atmospheric]] conditions and how the explosion occurred. The explosion, or burst, can be air, surface, subsurface, or [[seawater]]. An air burst will produce less fallout than a comparable explosion near the ground due to less particulate being contaminated. Detonations at the surface will tend to produce more fallout material. In case of water surface bursts, the particles tend to be rather lighter and smaller, producing less local fallout but extending over a greater area. The particles contain mostly sea salts with some water; these can have a cloud seeding effect causing local rainout and areas of high local fallout. Fallout from a seawater burst is difficult to remove once it has soaked into porous surfaces because the fission products are present as metallic ions which become chemically bonded to many surfaces. For subsurface bursts, there is an additional phenomenon present called "base surge". The base surge is a cloud that rolls outward from the bottom of the subsiding column, which is caused by an excessive density of dust or water droplets in the air. This surge is made up of small solid particles, but it still behaves like a fluid. A soil earth medium favors base surge formation in an underground burst. Although the base surge typically contains only about 10% of the total bomb debris in a subsurface burst, it can create larger [[radiation]] doses than fallout near the detonation, because it arrives sooner than fallout, before much [[radioactive decay]] has occurred. For underwater bursts, the visible surge is, in effect, a cloud of liquid (usually water) droplets with the property of flowing almost as if it were a homogeneous fluid. After the water evaporates, an invisible base surge of small radioactive particles may persist.
Meteorogically, snow and rain will accelerate local fallout. Under special [[meteorological]] conditions, such as a local rain shower that originates above the radioactive cloud, limited areas of heavy contamination just downwind of a nuclear blast may be formed. Rain on an area contaminated by a surface burst changes the pattern of radioactive intensities by washing off higher elevations, buildings, equipment, and vegetation. This reduces intensities in some areas and possibly increases intensities in drainage systems; on low ground; and in flat, poorly drained areas.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/library/policy/army/fm/3-6/3-6ch3.htm | title = Biological Agents And Nuclear Detonations | accessdate = 2007-05-11 | author = Global Security.org | date = April 28, 2005 }}</ref>

Hansen]] and [[Christopher R. Johnson]] that serves as a survey of the field of [[scientific visualization]] by presenting the basic concepts and [[algorithms]] in addition to a current review of visualization research topics and tools.{{cite web|title=Description for "Visualization Handbook"|url=https://www.amazon.com/Visualization-Handbook-Charles-D-Hansen/dp/012387582X|publisher=Academic Press|accessdate=5 April 2017|language=English|date=29 December 2004}} It is commonly used as a [[textbook]] for [[scientific visualization]] [[Course (education)|graduate courses]].{{cite web|title=Blue Waters Project to Offer Graduate Visualization Course in Spring 2015|url=http://www.scientificcomputing.com/news/2014/08/blue-waters-project-offer-graduate-visualization-course-spring-2015|website=Scientific Computing|accessdate=5 April 2017|date=18 August 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Chen|first1=Min|title=Visual Analytics|url=http://www.cs.ox.ac.uk/teaching/courses/2016-2017/visual/|website=Oxford University Department of Computer Science|accessdate=5 April 2017|language=en-gb}} It is also commonly [[Citation|cited]] as a reference for [[scientific visualization]] and [[computer graphics]] in published [[Academic publishing#Scholarly paper|papers]], with almost 500 citations documented on [[Google Scholar]].{{cite web|title=Citations for The Visualization Handbook|url=https://scholar.google.com/citations?view_op=view_citation&hl=en&user=UqyaAQQAAAAJ&citation_for_view=UqyaAQQAAAAJ:qjMakFHDy7sC|website=Google Scholar|date=1 January 2011}} ==Table of Contents== *PART I - Introduction #Overview of Visualization - [[Kitware|William J. {{Coord|display=title|55|50|0|N|37|37|0|E|type:landmark_region:RU}} [[File:VVC weather station.png|200px|thumb|VVC weather station location]]
The '''VDNKh weather station''' is the principal [[weather station]] in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]]. It opened in 1948 on the grounds of the [[All-Russia Exhibition Centre]]. Temperature and precipitation readings at VVC weather station form the official weather reports and historical statistics.
The station's World meteorological organization classification index is 27612.
<gallery> File:ВВЦ1.jpg|View to North-West File:ВВЦ2.jpg|View to West File:ВВЦ3.jpg|View to South-West File:ВВЦ5.jpg|View to East </gallery> <gallery> File:ВВЦ7.jpg|View to North-West File:ВВЦ9.jpg|View to South-West File:ВВЦ10.jpg|View to North File:ВВЦ11.jpg|View to South </gallery>

{{Use British English|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} [[File:Rossparty1914.jpeg|thumb|300px|Members of the Ross Sea party, photographed in 1914. Victor Hayward is standing, second from left, back row. [[Ernest Joyce]] is standing, extreme left of picture. [[Aeneas Mackintosh]] is seated, middle row, third from left.]] '''Victor George Hayward''' [[Albert Medal (lifesaving)|AM]] (1887–1916) was a London-born accounts clerk whose taste for adventure took him to [[Antarctica]] as a member of [[Sir Ernest Shackleton]]’s [[Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition]], 1914–17. He had previously spent time working on a ranch in northern Canada and this experience, combined with his "do-anything" attitude, was sufficient for him to be engaged by Shackleton as a general assistant to the [[Ross Sea party]], a support group with a mission to lay depots for the main cross-continental party.
Hayward quickly proved himself to be hard-working and resourceful. He was one of the ten members of the shore party that was marooned when the Ross Sea party’s expedition ship ''Aurora'' broke from its [[McMurdo Sound]] moorings during a storm and was unable to return. In difficult circumstances he played a full part in the efforts of the stranded group to fulfil its mission, despite its shortages of food, proper clothing, and equipment. During the main depot-laying journey on the [[Ross Ice Shelf|Great Ice Barrier]] in 1915–16 Hayward was one of the six who marched to the [[Beardmore Glacier]] to lay the last of the required chain of depots. On the return leg the party was struck with scurvy, which caused the death of [[Arnold Spencer-Smith]]. Although suffering badly himself, Hayward helped bring the rest of the party off the Barrier to the relative safety of the [[Hut Point]] shelter.
Hayward disappeared on 8 May 1916 while walking across the frozen surface of McMurdo Sound in the hopes of reaching the expedition’s base at [[Cape Evans]]. His body was never found. Seven years later Hayward was posthumously awarded the [[Albert Medal (lifesaving)|Albert Medal]] for his efforts to save the lives of his stricken companions on the Barrier journey.
==Early life== Victor George Hayward was born 23 October 1887 at 5 Manor Park Road, Harlesden, North London. He was the 12th of 14 children of Francis Checkley Hayward and Mary Jane Fairchild. His father became a senior executive of the London and North Western Railway.<ref>Peter Hayward, Great Nephew</ref> Hayward was educated at an [[Essex]] boarding school, and after attending a London business college was employed as an accounts clerk in the [[City of London|City]]. From an early age he had been fascinated by stories of adventure, a particular favourite, acquired as a [[Sunday School]] prize, being [[R M Ballantyne]]’s ''The World of Ice, or Adventures in the Polar Regions''.<ref name = "Tyler-Lewis_39">Tyler-Lewis, p. 39</ref> Unprepared for a life of "bourgeois complacency",<ref name = "Tyler-Lewis_39">Tyler-Lewis, p. 39</ref> Hayward took leave from his employers to spend seven months working on a ranch in northern Canada. On his return he found settling back into an office routine difficult, and applied to Shackleton’s office for a position on the newly announced Trans-Antarctic expedition. His offer to "do anything" secured him his place in the Ross Sea party.<ref name = "Tyler-Lewis_39">Tyler-Lewis, p. 39</ref>
==Ross Sea party== {{Main|Ross Sea party}}
===First season=== The Ross Sea party’s expedition ship ''Aurora'' arrived in Antarctica in January 1915. During the short season before the onset of winter Hayward volunteered for everything—helping [[Ernest Joyce]] with the dogs,<ref>Bickel, p. 45</ref> assisting the motor tractor party and [[manhauling|man-hauling]] depot supplies on the Barrier.<ref>Tyler-Lewis, pp. 84–87</ref> When the shore party was marooned after ''Aurora'' was blown from her moorings, Hayward became an accomplished seal hunter, helping to boost the party’s depleted stocks of food.<ref>Tyler-Lewis, p. 131</ref> Described as a "quiet, brawny man",<ref>Bickel, p. 121</ref> Hayward’s closest bond was formed with the party’s leader, [[Aeneas Mackintosh]], with whom he shared a common yearning for home and loved ones.<ref>Mackintosh had recently married, Hayward was engaged to be married. He kept an expedition journal in the form of a series of letters to his fiancée.</ref>
===Second season=== The main depot-laying journey of the expedition began in September 1915. Although privately recording that he thought the programme to be followed "impossible",<ref>Tyler-Lewis, p. 149</ref> Hayward threw his physical might into the job.<ref>Tyler-Lewis, p. 180</ref> He was one of the party of six that undertook the longest stage of the depot-laying journey, from 80°S to the Beardmore Glacier. This journey was completed on 26 January 1916.<ref>Huntford, p.480</ref> On the return journey [[Aeneas Mackintosh|Mackintosh]] and parson/photographer Arnold Spencer-Smith fell victims to scurvy and had to be carried on the sledge, drawn by Joyce, [[Ernest Wild]], [[Richard W Richards|Dick Richards]] and Hayward. When the food situation became acute Hayward, by now showing scurvy symptoms himself, nevertheless went forward with Joyce and Richards to obtain life-saving food and fuel for the rest of the party.<ref>Bickel, pp. 156–57</ref> Eventually, after suffering both physical and mental breakdown,<ref>Huntford, p. 485</ref> Hayward was lashed to the sledge and on 18 March was hauled to the shelter at [[Hut Point]] where, since the doorway was iced up, he was hoisted in through the window.<ref name="Fisher, p. 409">Fisher, p. 409</ref> Spencer-Smith died and was buried in the ice; Mackintosh barely survived. Joyce had expected Hayward to die,<ref>Tyler-Lewis, p. 191</ref> but he too survived.
===Disappearance=== [[File:Mackintosh walk.png|thumb|McMurdo Sound, frozen over. Mackintosh and Hayward set out on 8 May 1916 from [[Hut Point]] (A), intending to walk across the ice to [[Cape Evans]] (B). They disappeared in the area marked C.]] Helped by a diet of seal—plentifully available around Hut Point—the party slowly recovered. Mackintosh was anxious that as soon as possible they make the final stage of the return journey—the {{convert|13|mi|km}} across the frozen surface of McMurdo Sound to the base at Cape Evans. The ice would not be safe until winter set in, in June or July, but Mackintosh and Hayward grew impatient. In early May they had recovered sufficiently to begin testing the ice.<ref name="Fisher, p. 409"/> On 8 May Mackintosh announced that he and Hayward intended to walk across to Cape Evans, and against the urgent pleadings of Joyce, Richards and Wild, they set out at 1:00 pm., carrying only light supplies. Two hours later a blizzard swept over the Sound and they were lost from view.<ref>Fisher, p. 410</ref> They did not arrive at Cape Evans, and no trace of their bodies was ever found, nor was the nature of their fate established. They may have fallen through the ice, or been carried out to sea when the ice broke up. If by chance they had managed to reach the temporary safety of land they would have been cut off, without hope either of returning to Hut Point or reaching Cape Evans, and would have perished from hypothermia.<ref>Tyler-Lewis, p. 234</ref>
==Albert Medal==
After the remainder of the Hut Point party had crossed to Cape Evans in mid-July a series of searches instituted by Joyce failed to establish the fate of Mackintosh and Hayward.<ref>Tyler-Lewis p. 237</ref> Further searches took place when ''Aurora'' finally returned to relieve the party, in January 1917. A memorial cross was erected to Mackintosh and Hayward at Wind Vane Hill, a weather observation post near Cape Evans.<ref>Tyler-Lewis, p. 240</ref>
Seven years after their struggle on the ice, in belated recognition, on 4 July 1923 Joyce, Richards, Wild and Hayward (the last two posthumously, Wild having died on active service in 1918) were awarded the [[Albert Medal (lifesaving)|Albert Medal]], in recognition of their efforts to save the lives of Mackintosh and Spencer-Smith on the Barrier.

The '''Weizmann Women & Science Award''' is a biennial award established in 1994 to honor an outstanding woman scientist in the [[United States]] who has made significant contributions to the scientific community. The objective of the [[List of prizes, medals, and awards for women in science|award]], which includes a $25,000 research grant to the recipient, is to promote [[women in science]], and to provide a strong role model to motivate and encourage the next generation of young women scientists.<ref>http://www.weizmann.ac.il/WomenInScience/weizmann-women-science-award Presentation of the Weizmann Women & Science Award </ref>
The award was originally given by the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science (ACWIS) and now it is awarded by the [[Weizmann Institute]] and the award ceremony takes place at the Weizmann Institute.
The Weizmann Institute is a center of basic interdisciplinary scientific research and graduate study, addressing crucial problems in technology, medicine and health, energy, agriculture and the environment.
==Honorees<ref>http://www.weizmann.ac.il/WomenInScience/women-science-award/recipients List of recipient of the Weizmann Women & Science Award</ref>== * 1994 [[Joan A. Steitz|Dr. Joan Argetsinger Steitz]], a Henry Ford II Professor of Biophysics and Biochemistry at Yale University and an Investigator of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. * 1996 [[Vera Rubin|Dr. Vera Rubin]], Observational Astronomer, Department of Terrestrial Magnetism, Carnegie Institution * 1998 [[Jacqueline Barton|Dr. Jacqueline K. Barton]], Arthur and Marian Hanisch Professor of Chemistry at the California Institute of Technology. * 2000 [[Carla J. Shatz|Dr. Carla J. Shatz]], Nathan Marsh Pusey Professor and Chair, [[Department of Neurobiology, Harvard Medical School]] * 2000 [[Mildred Dresselhaus|Dr. Mildred Dresselhaus]], Institute Professor of Electrical Engineering and Physics, Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Received the Millennial Lifetime Achievement Award * 2002 [[Susan Solomon|Dr. Susan Solomon]], Senior Scientist, Aeronomy Laboratory, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration * 2004 [[May Berenbaum|Dr. May Berenbaum]], Swanlund Professor; Head, Department of Entomology, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign * 2006 [[Mary-Claire King|Dr. Mary-Claire King]], American Cancer Society Research Professor of Genome Sciences and Medicine, University of Washington, Seattle * 2008 [[Elizabeth Blackburn| Dr. Elizabeth Blackburn]], researcher at the University of California, San Francisco * 2011 [[Catherine Bréchignac| Dr. Catherine Bréchignac]], President of the International Council for Science and former president of the CNRS ("National Centre for Scientific Research") * 2013 [[Susan Gasser|Prof. Susan M. Gasser]], Friedrich Miescher Institute for Biomedical Research, Switzerland * 2015 [[Barbara Liskov|Prof. Barbara Liskov]] computer scientist and Institute professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) * 2017 [[Ursula Keller|Prof. Ursula Keller]] and [[Naomi Halas|Prof. Naomi Halas]]
==See also== * See also [[List of prizes, medals, and awards for women in science]]

Crow | publisher = | president = | editor = | staff = | foundation = 1922 | political = | language = English | ceased publication = | relaunched = | headquarters = [[Greenwood Village, Colorado]] | circulation = | circulation_date = | circulation_ref = | readership = | sister newspapers = | ISSN = | oclc = | RNI = | website = {{URL|https://www.wlj.net}} | free = | dirinteractive = | publishing_country = | publishing_city = }}
The '''''Western Livestock Journal''''' is a weekly livestock industry newspaper. Originally called the ''Farm and Ranch Market Journal'', it was started by Nelson R. Crow in 1922 and is published by Crow Publications.
==History== The ''Farm and Ranch Market Journal'' became ''Western Livestock Journal'' in the early 1930s. In 1952, Nelson purchased ''Livestock Magazine'' from the Biggs family in [[Denver]]. The two weeklies were combined in the ’70s to create one national edition of ''Western Livestock Journal'' and the monthly magazine was renamed ''Livestock Magazine'', and split into three editorial editions. ''Livestock Magazine'' ceased publication in the early ’80s.
==Today== Crow Publications publishes the ''Northwest American Bull Guide'' magazine (yearly), the ''Commercial Cattle Issue'' (yearly), the ''Properties Ranch & Home magazine'' (quarterly), as well as the ''Western Livestock Journal'' (weekly). Crow Publications/''Western Livestock Journal'' is located in [[Greenwood Village, Colorado|Greenwood Village (CO, United States)]].
== Further reading == * Pete Crow, [http://npaper-wehaa.com/western-livestock-journal/2012/01/11/#%3Fdpg%3D1/ "Nelson Crow, WLJ's Founding Leader"], ''North American Bull Guide'', January 16, 2012
[[Category:American weekly magazines]] [[Category:Agricultural magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1922]] [[Category:Magazines published in Colorado]]
{{Livestock-stub}}
